participants.participant: Peter Löscher, President and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to our Fourth Quarter Fiscal 2010 Analyst Conference in London and the simultaneous webcast. Our President and CEO, Peter Löscher and our Chief Financial Officer, Joe Kaeser will present to you Q4 and full fiscal year results, as well as wrap up of our successfully completed company program Fit4 2010.

In addition, Peter will give an overview on Siemens strategic framework for value creation One Siemens, and an outlook for fiscal year 2011. All documents can be downloaded from our website. You will also find a replay of the webcast which will be available soon after the conference. I would like to refer to our Safe Harbor Statement on page number two of the presentation. After the presentation, we will have time for Q&A.
And with that, I would like to hand over to you, Peter.

Thank you very, very much. Good afternoon to everybody. I think we have to cover a lot of ground today, so let's go straight into the achievements and then I would like to quickly update you on the path forward for Siemens towards continuous improvement and capital efficient growth. I will also introduce to you the new strategic framework, One Siemens where we will outline to our strategic direction and the significant strengths of our company and also as part of it, outlining the financial target system that will guide our actions in the future.

Strong operational performance in the last quarter; outstanding 2010 performance also relative to competition in Q4. Order intake gained momentum driven by major customer wins in energy, revenue growth stabilized further. The sectors again improved their efficiency and competitive positions. 10 divisions delivered a higher profit over an already strong fiscal '09, but the Q4 net result was also heavily impacted by project and restructuring charges and by the non-cash effective diagnostics impairment what all of you are well aware of.

Q2 closed on – closed a record year for our cash. All stakeholders should participate from the excellent performance in fiscal '10. Therefore, we have proposed a significant dividend increase to €2.70 in recognition of the outstanding work what everybody has done in the Siemens organization. We have also given a special bonus for the non-management employees totaling €310 million.

This quarter marks the end of a strong fiscal '10 and the successful completion also of the Fit4 2010 program. Let me just give to you a couple of highlights. We achieved over the last four years the two times GDP growth target. On average compounded annual growth rate, the operational sector profitability is either better or is par with our competition. Our cost reduction efforts in SG&A and supply chain management have paid off and our balance sheet is a strong source of growth. And all of this has been accomplished during a very difficult economic environment.

Let's have a closer look at the Q4 numbers in detail. New orders were up very strongly, 18% year-over-year growth and this came across the entire organizations with particularly strength in the emerging markets like Russia, India and Brazil. Revenue rose 2% above Q4 2009 and confirms that we are back on a sustainable growth track, the book-to-bill was also very encouraging with 1.11.

As I said, the total sector profit was mainly hit by the DX-impairment charges of €1.2 billion euros as well as by the charges in Industry, Solutions and Particle Therapy. And together with the SIS restructuring charges, this added up to a net loss for the quarter.

We saw particularly a very, very strong cash flow development of almost €3 billion, which is close to the 2009 level and Joe will talk about it in more detail. The divisional picture for the quarter on the right-hand side of the slide looks not only good for Q4, but also is encouraging in terms of the growth momentum what we see across our businesses.

You can see the very positive order intakes and sales growth numbers across all – nearly all divisions. In Industry, we saw a continued momentum and this was based by a double-digit order and revenue growth in the short cycle businesses like Industry Automation also around motion control within direct – within DT. And increased demand in Industry Automation was also a broad-based across all businesses in all regions. Margin in Industry Automation were helped by top line growth of higher capacity utilization. OSRAM saw its most profitable year ever and also regained pre-crisis volume levels.

We grew the LED share now to 21% in the fourth quarter and further benefited from healthy automotive demand. An upcoming global sales effort and capacity expansion will further spur the transition to LED. Building Technologies saw strong demand for energy efficiency solutions and from emerging markets. The Industry Solutions division had mixed performance. As we have said, the division took some significant restructuring charges as well as there were additional charges of €125 million for a project in the U.S. with a local partner, which hurt the margin.

On the positive side of the I&S Division, the division booked a number of large contracts in the Metals Division, adding up to a significant order intake increase. Mobility delivered again a very solid profitable quarter due to ongoing negotiations with customers. We have seen some large order postponements into 2011, but we're very confident about the current sales funnel.

In the sector Energy, again, Energy has delivered an excellent execution, delivered 13.1% profit margin, well in the target range and fossil, in particular, has an outstanding profitability supported by the consistent project delivery and favorable revenue mix with strong product and service content.

The overall Energy market continues to recover. The speed of recovery is different for each division. We clearly see large orders in many divisions and base business demand such as in Power Distribution has also picked up. The book to bill ratio for the Sector was again at a very strong 1.25 for the quarter.

Renewables is expanding very, very strongly, not just its global footprint, but also its backlog, it's now at a record €9.2 billion of order backlog. Profitability in the current quarter was impacted by a less favorable product mix and expansion efforts in wind and solar. And in the first half of fiscal 2011, we expect impact on profitability related to the further build up of the solar business and seasonal effects in the wind business.

Healthcare showed a solid 6% increase in order intake and a 1% revenue growth. Orders in Healthcare were particularly strong in the Americas where we will see – where we see positive effects from the release of the pent-up demand also in the United States.

Imaging and IT maintained the overall lead in profitability through a favorable product mix and above average growth of the service business. Profitability at Workflow and Solutions was burdened by the charges of €96 million associated with particle therapy. The charges stemmed from the tests of this prototype technology resulting in a revised assessment of the additional cost required to complete the projects.

Due to the FX movements in the final number of the non-cash Diagnostics impairment of €1.2 billion, operational Diagnostics showed an increase order intake of 4% in revenue growth mainly driven from the regions Asia and Australia.

At this chart, you can see that we have quite significantly build our order backlog over 2010, we have increased the order backlog by €6 billion, standing now at €87 billion excluding currency movements of around €3.5 billion, we were also increasing it, by the quarter. The factor of quantity and its high level margin quality give us a lot of confidence as we go into 2011, so we have not just increased order backlog in its totality but also when you look into the quality of the order backlog, it's very encouraging in terms of profitability.

The Energy sector remains the biggest contributor to the backlog with €53 billion and all divisions had significant order wins in Q4. Fossil, for example, won a number of turnkey contracts in India, in Oman, the Netherlands. We closed long-term service agreements in France, for a new plant and extended a contract in the Philippines both worth a total of €800 million, the Renewables division won a number of very large onshore and offshore wind parks in Europe and the United States, among them, Anholt with a 400 megawatt Denmark's largest offshore wind farm from DONG Energy, the Comber wind project in Canada from Brookfield Renewable Power, and in Transmission, we extended our leading position in offshore grid connections through the HelWin order worth €500 million.
And this wins demonstrate that the energy markets about to turn in a more positive direction and our integrated Energy portfolio gives us a unique competitive edge to win market share.

And there is one more order I want to highlight in the Industry sector, Mobility has succeeded to win a major order in the United States to sell its locomotives to the Amtrak as a customer and this has, for us, obviously also significance when you look ahead in terms of the rail programs, which are currently in discussion in the United States, so a great order win there as well.
And now, I would like to hand over to Joe.

Thank you very much, Peter. Very warm welcome to our Q4 conference here in London. Let me start with what I always like a lot especially if it turns out like that is free cash flow. And as you can see, we've been pretty much following the path, which has already been shown in prior years, maybe with the exceptions that there is no significant backlash in the first quarter or first month of the new fiscal year. You could see that from the beginning in 2010, we've been quite consistent in building up the free cash flow over time.

Obviously, one of the major contributors to that what we believe was a decent success and achievement for us that we've been consistently improving our growth times, been maintaining our net working capital terms, which now are stemming at 8.9 times revenues, which we believe is quite a decent achievement and supposed to be just about stable also going forward. So another question is what have been the reasons, why that has been developing like that, first of all, and secondly, what do we expect or how do we expect that to develop into fiscal 2011?

If you look at the slides here on page number eight, you can see basically the development of our bookings over time and then the billings – the development of our billings in excess also above that red bar. And for quite a long period of time, we've been able to increase the billings in excess, which means that our customers have helped finance us our working capital. We've seen some downturn during the course of 2009, which has not been continuing.

Now, we are at the similar pace of some volatile development in order – on pre-development of orders. If we model – if we model a situation where billings in excess and the behavior of our customer prepayments would change in a way that we cannot finance the working capital like we used to then that could be as much as 2 billion impact of the free cash flow in 2011. So, time will tell, but that's just something to consider. We have seen some developments – recent developments that our customers are less motivated in continuing with the current business model in terms of prepayments and financing over time.

The second topic where we have been pretty diligent on was the CapEx spending with business spending quite a lot of money when the cycle was developing from 2005 to 2007, even 2008, way above depreciation, and then we saw orders turning south. We obviously have also been putting the brakes on the CapEx spending. You see quite a correlation within the CapEx rate and the organic order growth, and we expect that to maintain that way going forward. So that means with a – with that clear order increase in 2011, we also expect CapEx to increase in a similar way.

We obviously are not spending them before the growth arrives but we just be prepared that we are going to be just at about 100% of depreciation in 2011. That again, will obviously have an impact of – into our free cash flow. And as you might remember depreciation has been in the neighborhood of 2.2, 2.3 billion in 2010, so if you are getting close to 100%, you are pretty much know what our growth impacted and growth driven CapEx expenditures are going to be in 2011.

Now the next chart, well basically get to but that also has to do with cash and that is basically how our pension fund has been developing over time. You could see if I may start from the bottom here, you could actually see that our fund people have been managing the fund pretty well in terms of actual return, have been able to yield 2.3 billion out of pension assets, which started to be 21.1 billion when we started fiscal year or ended fiscal year 2009 at 21.1.

However, during the course of the fiscal year, we've been seeing a massive deterioration of the discount rates going forward, you can see the discount rate which we have been using to discount our future obligations and that has been going down from 5.3 to 4.2. And those 110 basis points have had a massive, massive impact on, obviously, the funding status, which now has been increasing from a minus 4.0 to 6.4 billion. If you look forward, I think, there are only a few people who believe that the interest rates are going to change quickly any time soon and if they change it, probably have some further downward potential.

Secondly, it's our view that there are some longevity risks going forward, including, demographics. And then thirdly, at some point in time, inflation will be always become a matter to be considered too, which has actually two aspects as you know, the first one is that the discount rates go up, that also do benefit obligations.

So that's a – to cut a long story short, that's all considered. You have to be aware that 6.4 billion in pension deficit would be just about close to the maximum the company would feel comfortable in growing forward. And that would mean that we would need to address demographics, longevity and inflation in the pension fund.

So, we obviously need to look into solutions which also help us go up against inflation in the long-term, just to make sure our assets get protected. And we're looking into ways and areas on how we can ease the minds and the situation in the long term in that aspect.
Now, that much to the cash side of the company and the surrounding matters, let me now come to the other side, which is profitability and its impact also going forward.

Now, obviously, if you look into our income from continuous operations at the upper-left here on the slide, which has been showing quite a decent conversion of growth. Remember, we had actually a negative revenue environment, our revenues were down year-on-year and profitability has been up from continued operations. Some may believe it's not as much as it should have been. However, it's been significant there which has been 7% like-for-like and we've had several impacts on our OpEx as well as in the gross margin.

If we go to the gross margin first, the gross profit as you see, we've been expanding the margin, we've been increasing the gross margin not only in absolute but also in relative terms from 27 to 28.5%, which is 150 base points against the falling revenue, which is not always the usual aspect one would see also having deteriorating revenues. And there have been a few aspects why we were able to do that. First, we've had quite a favorable mix when we started fiscal 2010, at developing that into this – the half of 2010. The short cycle business environment, Industrial Automation, OSRAM, Drive Technology, Motion Control here for the most part has been growing the fastest. And they probably have been showing quite a decent profitability and also a decent drop to the bottom line. So favorable mix impact on the gross profit.

Second topic was that we've also, from a regional standpoint, have a quite favorable impact on the premium products, which mostly sold in Germany and that is – consider numbers. Germany has been up for quite a large number of percentages year-on-year. So two favorable mix impact, first, short cycle versus long cycle. Secondly, premium products, high innovation, high margin carrying products sold mostly in Germany and in parts of Italy and this is all be tool makers' high tech environment.

The second major impact has been on the purchasing side. Obviously, we've been encountering two facts. The first fact was a managerial performance, as you know, from our supply chain. We've had quite a decent result and performance on our supply chain initiative, not only in reducing the number of suppliers but also in terms of how it turned out to the bottom line. And secondly, admittedly, there has been some tailwind in negotiating with suppliers because it's been a buyers' market during the trough of industrial cycle.

Now going forward, and that actually has lead to the situation that the supply chain contribution to net income, called C&I, contribution to net income. has actually been bigger in euro than the price erosion has been in the market, okay. So has been able to over compensate the price erosion in the market fiscal 2010.

Now going forward, we do expect the 2011 to be different. We are not going to see tailwind in terms of product mix while the shorter cycle environment is still supposed to be growing, especially in Automotive and Toolmakers environment which is IABT and in part, also OSRAM. We do see a more significant part of the growth coming from the long-cycle environment, such as Mobility and less gross margin carrying assets and businesses.

So, there's not going to be any tailwind any more in terms of product mix, actually, it's the other way around. It will be slightly below. In terms of pricing, we do expect pricing to be up from current year – from the last year, last year it was just about 2.5% of sales. That could easily end up in 3 to 3.3% of sales for 2011, assuming that there will be a higher degree of market and competitive activity in mostly China. We do see several new entrants, especially in the T&D environment, mostly in the Transmission environment that could lead to some price erosion. We are back in the U.S. dollar range where obviously there is also some impact to be expected there. So the assumption in 2011 is a slightly higher price erosion from about 2.5 to 3, 3.3%, so these will be taken in consideration.

By the same token, we do not expect – we do not expect in our planning, we do not expect the C&I to again cover the price erosion in the market. That has to do with first of all that the low hanging fruits have been harvested, rightfully so. That secondly, the sentiment turns from a buyers into a more sellers related environment. And then thirdly, obviously, us shifting from the short-term action on negotiating power into a more long-term design-in related partnership with the suppliers. So don't expect a compensation of the C&I covering the market prices going forward. So that is important to understand also how we see 2011 and that eventually how that turns out into the guidance going forward.

Now obviously, on the other two parts which is R&D and SG&A, we are planning to invest a material amount of money into R&D, mostly engineering in 2011. You see we've been just about flat in terms of R&D spend in 2009 to 2010. We do expect 2011 to be up in both in quantitative absolute numbers as well as in relative numbers to revenues and that could be as much as 500 to 600 million investment for growth.

Similar aspects you can or should expect in the go-to-market part of the SG&A environment. We are very stable and pretty much cleaned up in the G&A environment. So, there's not going to be significant changes in the SG&A numbers in absolute terms but we do invest in applications specific go-to-market activities selectively in order to make good on what we have also in focus in terms of where growth comes from in the years to come.

So also expect some 300, 350 million investment into go-to-market expenses. As I said, SG&A flat and selling go-to-market including application specific activities in that ballpark. It's important to understand and it's gets much easier then also to get a view on where profitability ought to be.

So the good news – the good news in OpEx is that it is in our control to spend them. So we've cleaned up the base, through the SG&A program in terms of where we want to have the money at work. And now it's our decision based on our growth opportunities to invest money into engineering R&D as well as go-to-market. So it is something we decide or not to decide to invest into to the current plan how it will call for those numbers, which as I shared with you going forward. All right, so that much to the OpEx side and gross profit.

As I said, we're pretty clean and pretty well settled in the G&A part. There has been two major drivers for making that possible and have massively reduced complexity but also have been taking a lot of G&A costs out of the system by reducing the number of legal entities from 1,800 in 2007 all the way down to 995. So the Project 1000 has actually been successfully completed as one of the major enabler to reduce complexity; one of the few things Peter has been giving out in terms of transforming the company and also, of course, the reporting units have been also been brought down from 900 to 439 such as for the ones who've been or are just about to get concerned about the clarity and the in-depth reporting of the numbers.

So we do know, I do know, the company knows the P&L, the cost, the revenues, the bookings, major parts of the working capital for 439 different entities in the company. So we know exactly what's going on in terms of P&L and working capital, we haven't issues. So there is no lack of transparency for the company, we will know exactly where the laggards are and who make a lot of joy for us in terms of profitability and growth. So there is no lack of clarity of what needs to be done in the company.

In terms of finance bundling, it's another topic we are making pretty nice progress. So that will also keep the SG&A costs down not only in 2011 but also going forward. So no worry about G&A, very dedicated spending on go-to-market and then innovation-driven engineering and R&D OpEx going forward.

Now look at the second topic that might be of interest. This was happens below the so called below the line. You've seen here the bridge in terms of fiscal Q4, the equity investments were down 181 million that predominantly stem from the NSN challenges they continue to have going forward.

Restructuring of 383 million was the major driver for the reported loss in SIS and accounting, I'm sure you agree with me that 137 million profit in SFS is an outstanding result. We finally solved the Pick and Place matter with a loss of 92 million. And then there are a few smaller items like SRE which in absence of selling any assets, obviously there is – has also been turning out into a smaller loss.

The big number here in the 928 million on the so called corporate, pension and others, obviously, predominantly comes from the fact that we spend about 400 million or billed about 400 million on the reserves for employee related matters. About 300 as Peter mentioned earlier have been the appreciation campaign and the rest has been reserved for the upcoming incentive scheme to be paid out for the management going forward.

And then everything else, obviously, tax, as you can see have been pretty much in line. So what to expect going forward. On equity investments, we do believe that there will be an ongoing materially impact on NSN. As you know, Nokia has reported early this year that the NSN unit will have about 600 million, 500 or 600 million in restructuring, about 200 and change have been already done, so there will be restructuring coming into the fiscal 2011 on levels which were just about similar of what we have been seeing.

SIS basically in the main area has completed its restructuring. There will be some resource adjustments going forward, but basically we are competed here. SFS has had a peak earning year and that predominantly came from the fact that a lot of our – of their customers had actually prepaying back their loans because they had better opportunities in other markets. The debt markets and credit has been opening up at the different sources. There was some peak profitability here, which is not going to be coming again in 2011.

So, for 2011 we expect that pre-tax return equity, which was about 30% in 2010 to be back in the ranges of 23%, 25% which we consider to be a normal level. Considering that SFS is predominantly there for supporting our industrial business, and not as a purpose of itself. So that means less risk and it is in return on equity range between 23%, 25% and that also will turn into some EBIT number as you can probably figure out yourself.

CMPA, much smaller impact here. However, in order to look at this one, you need to consider there is about 2,000 people in this CMPA still who need to be managed, who have not been joining the new entity, which we need to manage till they are finally concluded. SRE will be volatile going forward, obviously because of the fact that we continue to be marketing our real estate assets depending on market conditions. So there will be ups and spikes in terms of gains and proceeds from those sales, but then again, this will be volatile over time. But the disposal strategy remains unchanged. That means we continue to transform long-term fixed assets into a more variable component going forward. And we also are pretty much on target with our REIP concept, which is supposed and targeted and committed to deliver 400 million of savings by 2012.

Corporate Treasury is straightforward, about 50 million a quarter should be doing it as a decent number. On corporate items and pensions, there are two metrics I wanted to draw your attention to. First, during the course of 2007 up to 2010, we've been accumulating cost at corporate, which actually were very operational cost, about the buildup of supply chain for example, the marketing and selling campaign of Siemens. We agreed to do that to make sure that there is not going to be any confusion about how the divisions have been achieving their target margins.

So we kept the definition for the target margins and their content as we had in 2007 all the way out to 2010, so that with a clean comparison about the achievements of the target. Now with Fit4 2010 having come to an end and us moving forward and putting an emphasis on a outside in benchmarking on relative performance to the market, we will allocate those operational costs, which have been carried at corporate to the sectors at division. And that will be about an 80 to 100 base point impact on the EBITDA margins of the sector. Okay, 80 to 100 base points impact to that. So, that means corporate items will be reduced and you'll see them distributed where are also then the benefits of those investments happen in the business.

The second topic is that the carve-out of the SIS entity will continue to have some cost related to making them a standalone, legal and operational and competitive entity in the IT environment. And those efforts will be carried under corporate items in 2011 till the companies are standalone and fully self-contained to compete in the IT environment. And that could also be a material amount one needs to consider in that area. So that much to basically all the line items you find below the line.
And with that, I hand it back over to Peter on the Fit4 2010. Thank you.

Thank you, Joe. On this chart, you just see once more the accomplishment what we have achieved in the Fit4 2010 program. On the top left hand side, the four times GDP, twice the GDP number, four percentage growth, the very good cash conversion rate, the profitability achievements in the sectors operationally, and then of course, the capital structure target, which we have deliberately decided actually not to achieve. But in the same time, we have also made significant strategic re-alignments, not just on the leadership culture aspects and leadership team aspects, we have also initiated a number of new joint ventures in a marketplace, for example, in for Mobility in Russia, for Power Generation in China. As Joe have highlighted – has highlighted that we have also maintained the R&D investments.

So overall, we have seen an excellent performance where Siemens is today. And going forward, we are now in a position to really close a chapter of 12 years of restructuring. And when you look back, this is exactly what has happened over the last 12 years. We are now in a position to be a leading company, a normal company. We're in attractive growth markets; we have two-thirds of our business already in number one or number two positions.

We have changed very much the attitude of our leadership team. We have aligned it with our shareholders for sustainable long-term and marking leading positions and it's clear to everybody that we've to continue to drive long term shareholder value creation. This means outperforming our competitors. This means being in the growth markets and growing fastest in the marketplace, maintain the top profitability what we've achieved independent but it's cyclic and the business cycles are in the current environment, and very important also to increase capital efficiency for the company overall, and that's precisely the new program what we called One Siemens. And if we try to summarize One Siemens, the key aspect before we go into the numbers, let me just summarize the key aspects.

One is, in the old program, we talked about our margins what we try to accomplish. In the new one, the EBITDA our target margins for the industries we are operating in over the cycle. And as you can see we anticipate that the industry cycles will be for Industry in the range of 10 to 15%, for Energy in the range of 10 to 15 and for Healthcare between 15 and 20. That's number one. The most important aspects of the new program is, the aspect of continuous improvement. Wherever we are, we continue to drive improvement, and we want to measure ourselves among the best, so the relative performance versus our direct competitors is a very critical element.

And just one word also how this is aligned with our incentive systems. In a couple of weeks, we will provide you with all the details of the new incentive systems, which will be part of the invitation for the Annual Shareholder Meeting, but let me just give you a flashlight what it will be.

Number one, that the annual bonus system will be exactly aligned behind the aspects of continuous improvement. If a business is unable to continuously improve performance, the management teams are unable to increase their pay-out, number one. Number two, on the – and you have to do this against competition, of course. Number two in terms of stock awards, the stock awards will be measured on two key criteria. One is EPS performance, and the other one is relative share price performance against a basket of competitors. And this just demonstrates to you, wherever we are, there is an enormous and strong incentive for the top leadership team of the organization to continuously to drive for improvement and that's – and then, we want to get rid of a system where we have tracked 23 targets, 23 KPIs.

We were talking about multiple initiatives. Now it is very simple. What is it the topline performance, how do we do relative to competition, where and how do we invest our capital and therefore, increase capital efficiency, and how do we drive free cash flow improvement? And therefore also, this is a critical element where we now have the clear focus when you look into where the incremental value drivers are for the organization. The key incremental value driver for organization is growth, capital efficient growth and therefore, we have really targeted the organization behind key growth initiatives.

Joe has just highlighted in terms of how we actually invest in a very targeted way our resources to drive for this growth. I will just in this regard really focus on two initiatives, one is our environmental portfolio, what you have seen, what we have already announced on Monday where we have clearly a target out there for increasing our environmental portfolio from 28 billion today to 40 billion by 2014.

And the second one is of course, we want to drive our emerging footprint, our emerging market footprint and on the left hand side, you can see what we anticipate that over 50% of the incremental growth of our markets will be in emerging markets. We already have a very strong emerging market footprint. On the top right hand side, you can see that we increased from 2005 to 2010 already up to almost a third of our business are currently already in the emerging markets. So, on the top right hand side of the business here, the target is continuous improvement. We will continuously improve our footprint in emerging markets and therefore, the SMART initiatives, therefore the application centers, which we're really putting down on the ground and therefore, the incremental investment there. We have already currently over 110,000 people in the emerging markets.

And the third, as I said, in our business. We want to drive and this is why this is linked to pioneering new markets, we want to pioneer very important new markets for Siemens like electro-mobility, like eCar, like smart grids, the whole issue in terms of where real big, big investments are happening currently in the global markets and this is behind sustainable urban city infrastructure developments and therefore, most recently as one example, we have announced our innovation partnership and alliance with Masdar City, where Masdar City, the first CO2-free city in the world, will be powered by smart grids and linking it to smart building solutions. All of these are examples where we are going forward to really continue to drive the aspect of capital efficient growth.

The key target will be organic, but we will supplement this with focused M&A activities behind these activities. We will continue to, as I said, to drive our SMART initiatives and we will have very targeted focused investment programs. And Joe has just highlighted what it means for the research and development aspects and what it also means for application centers, particularly in emerging markets.

And against this backdrop, we are changing fundamentally the approach for the company. Siemens is from an investor perspective, no longer a restructuring story. Siemens is a value story and this was the core reason why we felt strongly we also have to bring the dividend to a new level. And therefore, we want to propose at the Annual Shareholder meeting €2.70 per share, and you should expect from us continuity in our dividend policy as you have seen it in the past just at the different level going forward and this is the combination of the strength what we anticipate operationally, the strategic alignment and reposition – repositioning what we have achieved with our portfolio and realigning what we are doing with incentivizing our top leadership teams.

A last word on outlook 2011, we want to drive the increase from the organic order intake to show a clear increase compared to fiscal 2010 as you can see here on the chart, a moderate organic growth on the sales. This is simply to do as you know with the cyclicality of our long-term businesses. We have a very strong order book. We see, obviously, the order intake momentum going into 2011, and we anticipate this continue to be in our favor and we see the revenue growth moderately grow positively and the – and we also would like to have a new quality in terms of how we guide from the bottom line to the – from the top line to the bottom line.

And close another chapter what we have spent many, many hours and discussions together; what is above, what is below, what are the exceptions, what are not the exceptions? Now, it's very simple. It's a commitment for management where you can look how we are doing relative on a rolling quarterly basis on a growth versus key competitors and what is falling through at the continuing operation spaces after-tax and the rest is our responsibility, our commitment and this is, I think, also a new quality and this guidance is certainly meant not to disappoint. And with this, I would like to open it up, Joe and myself, for the questions what you have. Thank you.
Thank you, Peter. We'll start here at the second row, Peter and then for the back to Mark.

Good afternoon, sir. It's a Peter Reilly from Deutsche Bank. Three questions please; firstly, I would like to welcome the much higher dividend, it's very pleasing to see. You still have surplus capital on your own calculation on this basis and assuming you grow profitably that surplus capital is going to build up. So, what are your plans to do with that?

You obviously haven't done a special dividend this time. Do you plan to invest that money on acquisitions or can you talk about what your plans are there? Secondly, you're not that far off your return on capital target, can you talk about – do you have a time table to hit the return on capital target?
